results.title: For love or money: a history of women and work in Australia
results.creator_credit: Jeni Thornley, Megan McMurchy, Margot Oliver, Margot Nash and Flashback Films
results.brief_description: Tells the story of women’s working lives throughout Australia’s history. Juxtaposes clips from feature films, home movies, newsreels and documentaries with radio shows, diaries, popular songs, letters and interviews. Explores the challenges that face women in the nuclear age. Narrated by Noni Hazlehurst; edited by Margot Nash; music by Elizabeth Drake.

results.title: Red Matildas
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Sharon Connolly and Yarra Bank Films
results.brief_description: Through the lives of three women, Audrey Blake, May Pennefather and Joan Goodwin, “Red Matildas” explores the social and political conditions in Australia during the Great Depression - conditions of massive unemployment, widespread malnutrition and growing militarism at home and abroad, that provoked many people to political activity. May Pennefather served 12-18 months in the Spanish Civil War. Cinematographer: Laurie McInnes
results.creator_credit_for_label: Trevor Graham, Sharon Connolly and Yarra Bank Films

results.title: Bread and dripping
results.creator_credit: Margot Nash, Women's Film Collective and Wimins Films
results.brief_description: The role of the women during the Great Depression has often been neglected in the telling of Australian history. Using archival footage, this film illustrates the hardships and the political struggles women faced in a time of political and economic upheaval.

results.title: More smokes less lollies
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Timothy Read, Hilary Linstead, Film Australia, M and L and Big Picture
results.brief_description: Edited version of “Fourteen’s Good, Eighteen’s Better” and sequel to “Smokes and Lollies”, this is the second part in a planned four part longitudinal study of three young women in Adelaide who reflect on their past and futures as 18 year-olds: one single, another married and expeecting her first baby and the third divorced with two children. Each discusses her teenage years and attitude to marriage, sex and abortion. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gillian Armstrong, Timothy Read, Hilary Linstead, Film Australia, M and L and Big Picture

results.title: The Passionate industry: 1920-1930
results.creator_credit: Joan Long, Frank Bagnall and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “History of Australian Cinema Series”.
Traces the history of the Australian film industry in the decade 1920-1930. Includes material from fifty newsreels, sixteen feature films and still photographs drawn from our seventy collections. The program looks at the 1927 Royal Commission of Enquiry and Film Bill of 1927, as well as footage of the Regent, capitol and Old State Theatre of Melbourne.

results.title: Now you're talking
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Anthony Buckley and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Australian Cinema Series”.
The 30s saw the introduction of the “talkies” and a new era of filmmaking began. This was to decline with World War II. Excerpts from many of the films made during this decade are seen in this video. Please note that the commentary by Leo McKern has been recorded on another channel and may not be heard over the original sound recording. Includes b&w sequences.

results.title: Water birds of the inland
results.creator_credit: Norman Castle, Lilias Fraser, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows general feeding and nesting habits of a variety of inland water birds at Narran Lake, Western NSW (also known as Terewah Lake) and its surrounding marshy area.

results.title: News digest [No. 9]
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria and ABC
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Kyabram’s rodeo; 12,000 sea shells collected from the world’s beaches; Victoria’s first mobile water patrol equipped with a bar tender cruiser is launched at Sandringham; underwater enthusiasts collect relics from old steamers; movies on the move at the Myer Music Bowl shown by the State Film Centre on a 24 by 8 foot screen as part of the Moomba festivities.

results.title: Viewpoint on Adelaide
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The city of Adelaide, South Australia, as seen through the eyes of European migrants. Becoming accustomed to Australia was the main problem of migrants in this film. The language barrier, strange customs and the long hours of work required to become established are discussed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lilias Fraser, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: Sweet are the fruits
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the growing and harvesting of pears, apricots and peaches in the Ardmona District of Northern Victoria. Shows the huge cannery in operation at Mooroopna - grading, peeling, coring, cutting, filling cans, adding syrup and sterilizing, labelling, packaging and finally despatching cartons. Gives a picture of a worker’s typical day and life in the caravan park. Features Joan Harris and Frederick Parslow.
